BC-HOME-VIDEO-NYT 
HOME VIDEO: DVD UPDATE; WWII CLASSIC DOCUMENTARY; NEW RELEASES 

   (bl)  
 By PETER M. NICHOLS   
 c.1999 N.Y. Times News Service    

   DVD Showing Its Strength

   Late last year, signs in store windows summed it up: DVD is
here. After a sputtering start in 1997, more than 2,500 films were
available on the compact digital video disk and more than 1 million
players had been sold. Where do things stand?

   ``There's been safe growth _ the key word is safe,'' said Martin
Greenwald, president of Image Entertainment, a large distributor of
the disks. Safe is defined in two ways: The public is taking to the
new format in promising numbers, and the studios are not flooding
the market with too many disks.

   Suppliers like Greenwald measure success by returns from
retailers, which are low. ``That's the sign of a very healthy
marketplace,'' he said.

   Industry sources say that DVD is adding 80,000 to 90,000
households a month. The format is making particularly large strides
in chains like Tower and West Coast Video, a predominantly East
Coast chain that has a reputation for innovation. Steven Apple, a
vice president, said that 10 percent of West Coast inventory was
DVD, a high figure for such a new line.

   Dealers everywhere report keen consumer interest in new and
older films on DVD and an increasingly strong inclination to rent
disks as one would videocassettes. ``Initially, DVD is a sales item
because people want to immediately build a little library when they
buy the player,'' Apple said. ``Now that they have owned the
players for a year in some cases, they're interested in renting as
they would traditionally.''

   Heroism Amid the Flak

   Before World War II, William Wyler directed films like
``Wuthering Heights'' and ``The Westerner.'' During the conflict,
he jumped on a B-17 called the Memphis Belle and made a documentary
that stirred the country and brought tears to the eyes of Franklin
D. Roosevelt.

   The Belle was flying its 25th and last mission into Germany
before the crew would return to the United States. Wyler crawled
around the aircraft with a hand-held camera recording a
heart-stopping and often strangely beautiful drama, ``The Memphis
Belle,'' that stands up very well today on a tape from Antiquary
Video.

   The mission was to bomb naval installations at Wilhelmshaven on
the North Sea. ``The Hun is expecting us,'' rumbles the rhetorical
narration written for the folks at home. Bombers climb to freezing
heights and are strung across clear azure skies. Flak starts
arriving in black puffs and gradually fills the sky.

   The hardest part is the flight back to England. German fighters
come from everywhere. A 19-year-old waist gunner blazes away in all
directions. An engine is on fire. At the airfield, ground crews
count the returning planes. Colored flares signal ambulances from
B-17s carrying wounded. ``It's lost its nose,'' the narrator says
of one craft. ``The navigator is dead. The pilot is wounded. The
bombardier is wounded. There are no brakes, no flaps. The hydraulic
system is shot out.''

   Not on the Memphis Belle, however, which returns safely. Wyler's
film was reviewed on Page 1 of The New York Times on April 14,
1944.

   Information: (800) 225-0208.

   New Releases

   ``Everest''

   Removed from the eight-story-high Imax theater screen, David
Breashears' and Greg MacGillivray's account of the storied 1996
climb loses visual grandeur but still stands up as an account of a
brutal experience even for those who made it to the summit. Everest
takes everything to extremes. One climber is so badly wracked by
coughing fits that she cracks ribs. With the wind chill at minus
100 degrees, another climber is rendered temporarily blind and
later will have both hands amputated. At 20,000 feet rescue
helicopters lose control because their blades don't have enough air
to bite. Eight people from one party die. Others reach the summit,
however, including the production team who, Lawrence Van Gelder
wrote in The New York Times, shot an ``absorbing film and a story
of hope and hubris.''  

   1995. Miramax. $19.99. 48 minutes. No rating. Release date:
March 30.

   ``The Rugrats Movie''

   The talking babies of the Nickelodeon series try to get used to
the newborn addition in their midst, Dylan Preston (Dil) Pickles,
but find him unacceptably assertive right off the starting block.
Attempting to turn him back in, the Rugrats hop a ride in a
mattress truck, which crashes and spills them into a forest full of
danger. As in any such woodlands, there's a ravenous wolf, and in
this case a crazy bunch of circus monkeys who make off with Dil.
Given the popularity of the series, it's a movie that had to
happen. ``The pleasant surprise is that the film is a delight''
(Anita Gates).

   1998. Paramount. $26.95. 80 minutes. Closed captioned. G.
Release date: March 30.

   ``Home Fries''

   Serving as a reminder of how much Hollywood could use some good
screwball comedy, Dean Parisot's film at least reaches for a
bizarre situation. Sally (Drew Barrymore) is a waitress at the
local Burger-Matic and pregnant with the baby of a married man. The
wife of the father-to-be gets his two stepsons to buzz him in a
helicopter in order to scare him into mending his ways. Instead he
dies of fright. Suspecting that Sally can implicate them, one of
the stepsons (Luke Wilson) takes a job at the Burger-Matic and
falls in love with her. Well, the story ``at least has the right
attitude. It just isn't funny enough in its particulars'' (Stephen
Holden).

   1998. Warner. $107.37. 93 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13.
Release date: March 30.

   ``Safe Men''

   Two failed singers (Sam Rockwell and Steve Zahn) from
Providence, R.I., are mistaken for a pair of safecrackers (Mark
Ruffalo and Josh Pais) and are conned into grabbing an easy
$300,000 from an old man's safe. But that puts them under the thumb
of a local mob boss (Michael Lerner), which leads to their
participation in other jobs. Unfortunately, nothing grabs the
attention in a film that ``is far longer on dull talk than
inventively comic action'' (Van Gelder).

   1998. Universal. $99.36. 94 minutes. Closed captioned. R.

   Other new titles of interest, some of which may have had a
theater release at one time, appeared on television or been on
videocassette in earlier editions:

   ``TERROR 2000.'' Christoph Schlingensief's punk expressionist
fable lampoons neo-Nazism and xenophobia in contemporary Germany.
Looking into the disappearance of a social worker who was escorting
Polish immigrants to a refugee camp, a husband-and-wife detective
team run into one crazy adventure after another. Imagine, Stephen
Holden wrote in The New York Times, a Keystone Kops film ``written
by ``William S. Burroughs, peopled with characters from George
Grosz by way of Russ Meyer and directed in a style that suggests
Jean-Luc Godard on speed.'' 1994. Water Bearer. $29.95. 79 minutes.
German with English subtitles. Release date: March 30. Information:
(800) 551-8304.

   ``THE BLACK HOLE.'' It took ``Star Wars'' to launch Gary
Nelson's film about a madman who tries to fly a space ship into a
black hole. Accomplished special effects are the story here. The
cast wasn't too shabby either: Anthony Perkins, Maximilian Schell,
Ernest Borgnine, Roddy McDowall. 1979. Anchor Bay. $14.98. 97
minutes. Release date: March 30.

   ``MURDER IN A SMALL TOWN.'' Playing against type, Gene Wilder
makes a charming low-key amateur sleuth named Cash Carter. A
successful theater director, Cash has retreated to Stamford, Conn.,
to try to forget the murder of his wife. This being 1938, he gets
to carry on an old-fashioned romance with his girlfriend (Cherry
Jones) and run a local theater troupe. As for the case, a mean
fellow has been murdered and the police need Cash to solve the
case. A&E. $19.95. 96 minutes. Closed captioned. No rating. Release
date: March 30.
